Name: Information and the Nature of Reality: From Physics to Metaphysics (Canto Classics)

ReviewList.Text: This book, along with Paul Davies, The Goldilock's Enigma, are part of my rereading diet almost every day.  If I had read these books before I published my book, I would have referred to them because they hit on topics about information and consciousness that I consider to be vital to my personal growth.  I think any one wanting to graduate from materialistic thinking to more spiritual thinking will find this book invaluable.  I found John Haught's chapter, Information, theology, and the universe especially valuable.  He states what it takes to make meaningful information flow, i.e. enough, but not too much redundancy and novelty, consistent with a concept of evil as a bifurcated path of erroneous extremes on either side of the good.  I can see why the reviewers still mentally stuck in the mud of matter find the book hard to understand.  I recommend the book for any one ready to graduate from mind under matter to mind over matter.
I like every thing Paul Davies writes. He is a great physicist and can do metaphysics too. This book contains his trademark: a special way with words and ideas. A great read.

I really like philosophy and after years of reading "Big History," (i.e. history from the Big Bang onwards) and physics as well, I believe that information is one of the "core" properties of the cosmos, if you will.  Most philosophers seem to delight in writing in a convoluted fashion and most of the many authors in this book seem to take similar delight, which made it a slow read for me.  I think another book titled "Decoding the Universe" by Charles Seife is a better read and more coherent.

The concept that all reality is information and all information is reality. The universe is composed of bits of information.What does this meanfor our concepts, scientific, theological, biological? This book explores the ramifications of "realities". Caution: As in all books on information it must be read twice, at least.

A magnificent look at our reality from the vantage point of information theory. Anyone interested is how a movement away from materialism will impact world belief systems needs to read the expert opinions of physicists and theologians contained in this very special book.

I guess I was expecting so much more from the book, its title and table of contents that I can't give it more than 3 stars. I know it's extremely hard to try to get all these smart or famous authors to write about the same subject, in the same book, and worse yet, to try and edit their papers to match the book's intent. 3 or 4 chapters are extraordinary, 3 or 4 are OK, and the rest I found either too dense or too mainstream or too careful or too boring.

There is a lot of material in here from various disciplines all approaching "information" from their respective directions. Information has some technical meanings which are explored, while at the same time philosophers and physicists (scientists in general for that matter) have tried to make "information theory" the magic bullet that explains everything from the origins of the universe to the appearance of life and consciousness. Information theory is the latest fad in these disciplines. Nevertheless, while some of these applications are over-the-top, Davies and Gregersen have managed to snag an excellent stable of authors who are luminaries on the subject and the editing is superb! None of the papers is highly technical, and all make excellent reading if you are interested in the subject.

After having read The Goldilocks Enigma some time ago, and perused the last chapter, I have been waiting for a logical continuation of that Ultimate Explanation. Today, I have discovered it and enjoyed reading it. What surprised me, however, was that David Bohm was mentioned only ones. So, I expect a continuation of this discussion, which would include David's ideas and their relationship with Eastern philosophy and religions.
So very thorough, comprehensive, searching.  Mayhaps to much for even me, but I've found it truly enlightening on the spiritual level.
Really great and thought provoking book on the nature of the universe.

There's a few hours I won't get back. I can't stand deceptive advertising and misdirection. I was expecting some physics, what I got was a series of barely disguised religious rants. Yearning, longing, proselytising, desperate to convince us and themselves. Drowning us in a rich verbal sludge which leaves me at least shaking my head. What is all this crap. In my opinion a waste of time and dishonest. But it comes with the territory. Anything for the cause.
A most interesting book --- all students should read this early in their education. Information is a meta-concept.
